pageTitle: Moment of Inertia and Radius of Gyration | Engineering Mechanics Review
textBeforeTable: Moment of Inertia of Common Shapes   $\displaystyle I_{xy} = \int xy \, dA$ Product of Inertia   $k^2 = {\bar{k}}^2 + d^2$ $J = \bar{J} + Ad^2$ In the same manner, the transfer formula for polar moment of inertia and the radii of gyration are respectively   $d$ = distance between x and x’ $A$ = area of the section $\bar{I}$ = centroidal moment of inertia $I$ = moment of inertia about the x-axis $x$ = any axis parallel to the centroidal axis $x'$ = centroidal axis Where   $I = \bar{I} + Ad^2$   Transfer Formula for Moment of Inertia     $k_z = \sqrt{\dfrac{J}{A}}$ $k_y = \sqrt{\dfrac{I_y}{A}}$ $k_x = \sqrt{\dfrac{I_x}{A}}$ $k = \sqrt{\dfrac{I}{A}}$ Radius of Gyration   $\displaystyle J = \int r^2 \, dA$ $J = I_x + I_y$ Polar Moment of Inertia: Polar moment of inertia is the moment of inertia about about the z-axis.   $\displaystyle I_y = \int x^2 \, dA$ Moment of inertia about the y-axis:     $\displaystyle I_x = \int y^2 \, dA$ Moment of inertia about the x-axis: Moment of Inertia Moment of inertia, also called the
